Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RTP-9Y81-JBHT-D389-00000-00New call for special counsel to probe FISA abuses; Liberal media's Russia hysteria; Brit Hume's take on Nunberg interviews; Gary Cohn resigning after dispute over trade; GOP reps want special counsel to probe FISA; Gun control counselling at doctor's office; What's the meaning behind the new NRA ad?; Facebook's new chat app for kids2018-03-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:53ZLexisNexisNew call for special counsel to probe FISA abuses; Liberal media's Russia hysteria; Brit Hume's take on Nunberg interviews; Gary Cohn resigning after dispute over trade; GOP reps want special counsel to probe FISA; Gun control counselling at doctor's office; What's the meaning behind the new NRA ad?; Facebook's new chat app for kidsLanhamFULL TEXT

TUCKER CARLSON, FOX NEWS HOST, TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT: Good evening and welcome to TUCKER CARLSON TONIGHT.

House Republicans Trey Gowdy and Bob Goodlatte are demanding the appointment of a new special counsel to investigate the abuse of civil liberties by the DOJ and the FBI. We'll have the latest on that in just a minute.

But, first tonight, former Trump campaign aide Sam Nunberg went on television yesterday and the news world ground to a halt. Nothing else happened. Americans stopped dying of drug ODs, the world's post-war order stopped collapsing, robots stopped taking our jobs, the borders were secure because for most of the day, all that mattered was Sam Nunberg. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ERIN BURNETT, CNN HOST, " ERIN BURNETT OUTFRONT": Good evening. I'm Erin Burnett, "OutFront". Tonight, breaking news. Defiant and speaking out, Trump's former campaign aide Sam Nunberg refusing to comply with a grand jury subpoena in the Russia investigation.

DON LEMON, CNN HOST, "CNN TONIGHT": This is exactly what the White House did not want to hear. So, you have to wonder, what does Sam Nunberg really know.

WOLF BLITZER, CNN HOST, "SITUATION ROOM": Perhaps unprecedented comments from a former Trump campaign aide who says he's been subpoenaed.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: In the history of American news media, we have never witnessed anything like this.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Who writes news copy? Russian bots, non-English speakers for sure. Sam Nunberg speaking out.

Who is Sam Nunberg exactly? Well, I'll tell you. Just yesterday, he was a pretty obscure part-time political consultant from New York City, who has apparently been struggling with a substance abuse problem.

He's actually a pretty nice guy, but you have probably never heard of him. Almost nobody had heard of him. And now, the media are telling you that Nunberg could be the key to this whole scandal. The John Dean of this fake Watergate. Except that, unlike John Dean, Nunberg was nowhere near the decisions when they were made.

He worked at a low level of the Trump campaign before it was actually a campaign. He left almost a year-and-a-half before the election. If there was indeed a Russia conspiracy, Sam Nunberg would not know anything about it.

More likely, what was going on yesterday, Nunberg brilliantly played the press because it turns out, this Friday, he's talking to Robert Mueller's investigators, which is yet another measure of how absurd this independent counsel investigation is, if you're talking to Sam Nunberg.

Others, though, have been charged with perjury after doing interviews with Mueller's investigators. Nunberg will not be. Why? Because he just admitted in public to being an alcoholic and then acted like a lunatic on television for hours.

It is the perfect preemptive insanity defense. Mueller can't indict him. After yesterday, no jury would convict Sam Nunberg. Was that Nunberg's plan? Well, we don't know really. But if it was, none of the people interviewing him yesterday would have figured it out because there's nobody dumber than most cable news hosts at "CNN" and "MSNBC".

How dumb? Well, dumb enough to see Russian saboteurs under every bed. Russia, the place, the actual country, is grim and hopeless. It's got a lower than replacement birth date. It's got waning power on the world stage. It has one military base outside its borders. It's not a major player anymore.

But the imaginary Russia, the one you see on television every night, has never been more powerful. At the DNC and "NBC News", Vladimir Putin is diabolical and omnipotent. Putin put Trump in office. He gave the Senate nomination in Alabama to Roy Moore somehow. He empowered the NRA. He likely handpicked seasoned masters of espionage like Sam Nunberg and Carter Page to undermine our democracy.

It's delusional, but they fervently believe it. Meanwhile back in the real world, evidence mounts that the actual problem is not the Russians or Vladimir Putin, it is the corrupt and decadent and resolutely stupid leadership of our own elites.

That is why Trump got elected, in reaction to them. That's why the European Union is in the process of collapsing.

Just this weekend, in Italy, while we're all talking about Sam Nunberg, the ruling party there was crushed, while antiestablishment candidates won big. Voters, the polls showed, were deeply unhappy with economic policies that have enriched a few, while stealing the future from young people.

They hated the immigration policies that have crushed their national culture under waves of migrants. Sound familiar? Well, there, as here, the elites have failed.

But they can't admit that? They can't face their own failure. So, instead, they blame the unseen hand of Russia.

Former Obama official Samantha Power actually said that out loud in a tweet. Russia won the Italian election, she explained. Well, maybe Samantha Power and her friends at "MSNBC" and the rest have no choice but to keep pretending.

If our ruling class admitted the sad truth about Russia, they'd have to take responsibility for their own ineptitude and failures and they won't. And so, the insanity continues.

Christy Setzer is a Democratic strategist, president of New Heights Communications and a connoisseur of the Russia story and she joins us tonight.

So, Christy, this Italian thing happened. And I'm not saying it's the most important thing to happen this year, but it's another domino that is leading clearly toward the dissolution of the European Union, toward the order in Europe and in this country, by the way. Russia did that?

CHRISTY SETZER, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: It's possible that they played a role. It's possible. What we have seen - and these two things can both be true at the same time. It can, one, be true that organically, independently, we are seeing, across the globe, these movements that are populist, that are anti-immigrant that have a lot of different things in common.

And also, it's being true that Russia is sort of stirring the pot. We have recently found out that a Russian troll farm was spending a million dollars a month in 2016 in the US elections to sort of, again, stir the pot, to influence our elections by supporting Donald Trump and going -

CARLSON: The democrats spend over a billion - look, I'm not saying that Russia is not trying to destabilize the United States. What I'm saying is it's irrelevant. And if you look at the actual poll numbers, they show pretty consistently in a lot of different countries that people are dissatisfied with the leadership of the people in charge.

And that's why Trump got elected. That's why Brexit happened. That's why Scandinavia is about to turn. That's why we almost had Marine Le Pen in France.

And in each one of these cases, the elites rather than accept responsibility, blame an unseen foreign hand. You don't see a thread here?

SETZER: I think, as I just said, that both things can be true. It's true, on one hand, that there was unrest among the country that was unhappy with the leaders that they have been given for the last, I don't know, decade, couple of decades.

At the same time, it's also true that Russia has been grooming Donald Trump for years. At least that's what the Steele dossier says.

CARLSON: Hold on. I don't think it's fair or honest to say that the allegation is Russia is just helping populist or right-wing movements like Trump or Berlusconi or Marine Le Pen.

The claim is also that the Russians were helping Bernie Sanders. Right? And that they were helping Jill Stein.

SETZER: They were helping anti-Hillary Clinton. That's what they were doing.

CARLSON: They are paying for the most left-wing cable station there is, "RT". So, it's a little more complicated.

So, "Rolling Stone" -

SETZER: It's a pro-Russia station. It's not necessarily left wing. The two are not the same.

CARLSON: Maybe the obvious is true, which is that people in charge as represented by the morning show on "MSNBC", you know what I mean, like the people who have been making policy for the past 30 years haven't taken into account the views of voters and voters are mad about that.

And so, rather than like learn something from what's happening, they're blaming forces that aren't there, the Russians.

SETZER: The Russian forces are, in fact, there. And I think all you have to do is listen to not just Samantha Power, you can listen to any one of - you can listen to our own secretary of state. You can listen to Rex Tillerson.

CARLSON: But I don't care because none of those people is wise beginning with Samantha Power, whose foreign policy has left the region in tatters.

SETZER: She is also not in power.

CARLSON: She's not. But she's implicated in the disaster that is the world 2018 that democratic voters in democratic nations across the West are reacting against.

So, do you think there's any coincidence that the Russia hoax is being used to discredit anybody not on the right, but anybody who challenges power. You ever notice that?

SETZER: Obviously, I deeply disagree with calling it a Russia hoax. Again, if we can go back to what the origins of Russia "hoax" were, it went back to well-before the 2016 election.

But that's when we first learned about it, was, as you may remember, from one of the debates with Hillary Clinton when she talked about 17 intelligence agencies in the US have all concluded that Russia has been trying to meddle. And I hate that word because it's so weak. But have been trying to influence US elections.

We didn't listen to that story because -

CARLSON: No evidence has emerged from that date till now that it's real. I want you to think about something that was written in "Rolling Stone" today by a very left-wing writer. This is someone who hates Trump, who is a full-on lefty and he said this.

"By an amazing coincidence, virtually all the anti-system movements and candidates that so terrified the political establishment just two years ago have since been identified as covert or overt Russian destabilization initiatives run by Putin."

It's not clear to you that this is a reaction against voters who are mad because nothing is working for them. And rather than listen to them, the elites are like, oh, it's not our fault, it's Putin's fault. You don't see that at all.

SETZER: I think - one more time -

CARLSON: Or you just think that's part of it or no? I keep asking the question because I'm amazed that someone as smart as you doesn't see that what ties claims that implicate Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump is maybe defensiveness on the part of the people in power. You don't see that?

SETZER: I believe that both things are true. I believe that there is populist unrest in our country in 2016. I also believe that the Russians both saw that, leveraged it, took advantage of it and kind of fanned the flames of it, so that they could install somebody that they saw as willing to -

CARLSON: But there's no evidence they did that.

SETZER: There's plenty of evidence that they did that.

CARLSON: It's insane.

CARLSON: Go back to the Trump Tower meeting. They were offered -

CARLSON: I can't even - wanted to keep this at a higher level because when we get right down to the details, it gets so frustrating that I can't continue. Christy, thank you so much.

SETZER: Tucker, thank you.

Brit Hume is Fox's senior political analyst and he joins us. Brit, you've been in the media for a long time and television for many decades.

When you saw Sam Nunberg on yesterday, did you think to yourself, I would have put him on if I were a bureau chief or I wouldn't have put him on if I were bureau chief?

BRIT HUME, FOX NEWS SENIOR POLITICAL ANALYST: Well, I very much hoped, Tucker, that I would not have. And it was worth noting that, before the day was over, "CNN's" Erin Burnett had looked at him and said, I smell liquor on your breath. Could she have been the first and only "CNN" anchor to notice that the guy was probably drunk?

Not only that. He's plainly a very troubled soul.

As a journalist, when you come along, you don't have to make a psychiatric diagnosis to recognize that somebody you're talking to may not be OK and that whatever this person says may be indeed questionable.

And yet this guy held sway over the airwaves, as you pointed out earlier, for hours on end, particularly on "CNN", but I guess others picked it up and it got quite a ride yesterday.

And, of course, the principal thing that made the headline, Tucker, was when he said that he wasn't going to cooperate with Mueller. Well, by this morning, that was gone all and he said indeed he was going to cooperate with Mueller. As a matter of fact, he has very little choice.

But that was a non-story that lived all day long because it feeds this whole narrative that there's something terribly wrong and that we have an unqualified president under the influence of Russia and God knows what else.

CARLSON: And so, to make that point, you have someone who is under the influence of alcohol to jump around the set and humiliate himself. And not only that, degrade the person who is interviewing him. I wonder if there's a cost long-term when you do stuff like that.

HUME: Well, Tucker, what we're looking at here is that there's been a belief for the longest time that the Trump election was illegitimate and there's been a sense in the media that his election constitutes a kind of national emergency because he's such an unqualified character, and so likely to lead us off a cliff that it is the job of the media to join the resistance and to find out what must be behind his election and what scandals must lurk there in order really to take him down.

I mean, I think that's plainly what this is all about. The media have clearly joined the resistance. And the coverage of this, I think, has been, in the mainstream media at least, extremely one-sided, a lot of it misguided. There have been any number of stories that turned out badly all along the way.

You'll remember "CNN", the group of their senior people sitting that they had word that when Comey testified that he was going to testify that he had never told Donald Trump that he was not under investigation and the next day, of course, Comey came out and testified just the opposite.

You wonder how stories like that - and there have been several of them - can possibly get past these seasoned journalists if they're not on a crusade. And I think they are.

CARLSON: I remember when the Russians hacked the national power grid. Do you think it might help - oh, but they didn't, of course. Do you think it might help the rest of us who are getting agitated watching this just to remind ourselves that what you're seeing is political advocacy? There's no expectation of objectivity or news. What you're watching is one side waging partisan battle against the other?

HUME: Yes. But it's strikingly effective. Your previous guest, she really didn't want to let go of the narrative that's out there that Russia had an important effect on the election.

The evidence of that, as you pointed out, is extremely light at best. Anything that Russia did to the tune of even a million dollars a month is dwarfed by the rest of the spending and the other things that influenced the outcome of elections.

But it's something that is held on to for dear life. And I think it's the story of coverage. I think it's enraged the people who see things more clearly than that, but on and on it goes.

You see it particularly in the character assassination of Devin Nunes, the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, who has had to put up with unbelievable assaults on him. And they continue to this day that he's the guy who is at fault when you know that, on the Democratic side, feeding the press, there's this unbelievable leak fest out of that committee and it goes on and on. Not a proud moment for the America news media in my judgment.

CARLSON: It's true. Heilemann over at "MSNBC" called Nunes "a Russian agent". Two years ago, you'd be fired for saying something like that if you couldn't support it, but he's, obviously, not going to.

HUME: It borders on hysteria. It's just so over the top. I mean, you don't have to be a Trump admirer to realize that the things that are being said are just wildly out of proportion to anything real beneath them.

CARLSON: Well, it's insane. I know people who hate Trump who agree with that completely, to be honest. Brit, thank you very much.

HUME: You bet, Tucker.

CARLSON: We've got a Fox News alert. Another fixture of the Trump administration is stepping down. National Economic Council Director Gary Cohn says he's planning to leave the administration. Why?

Well, Fox chief national correspondent Ed Henry joins us tonight with details. Hi, ed.

ED HENRY, FOX NEWS CHIEF NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: Tucker, great to see you. Shortly after fresh denial from President Trump, there's simply no truth to the idea that he can't bring stability to his White House, his lead economic adviser is heading for the exits.

Well, the president is right that there's turnover in every White House, Democrat or Republican, there's been a particularly large number of departures lately from Hope Hicks to Rob Porter, multiple press secretaries, communications directors, national security advisers and chiefs of staff.

What's significant about Gary Cohn is he was a key architect of the tax cut, plus the regulatory reform that has really propelled this economy with the markets getting a lot more volatile in recent weeks. There's no denying this a big loss for the president.

And while he lost a high-profile battle to try and stop the president from moving forward on those tariffs on aluminum and steel, White House officials tonight are insisting Cohn is not running out just because of that one dispute.

But, in fact, it was two months ago today, the president boasted he wanted Cohn to stick around for a "long time".

This is going to feed the mainstream media narrative you've been talking about that there's chaos at the White House, but as the president noted today, he likes conflict, he likes different points of view on trade, other issues. Diversity of thought, after all, is something that's supposed to be celebrated.

And it was former chief of staff Reince Priebus who said over the weekend, critics may pounce on a meandering process of the White House, but the focus should be on the results the president is getting. Not sure a lot of people will agree with that or report that, but that is what his former chief of staff said, Tucker.

CARLSON: Ed Henry, ladies and gentlemen.

HENRY: Good to see you.

CARLSON: Good to see you. Thanks.

Top Republicans in the House are tonight demanding a new special prosecutor to investigate abuses of civil liberties by the FBI. What does that mean? Will it happen? We've got details coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CARLSON: Top House Republicans are tonight formally calling for a second special counsel. House Oversight Chairman Trey Gowdy of South Carolina and Judiciary Chairman Bob Goodlatte of Virginia say a new investigation, an independent one, is needed to look into abuses of FISA surveillance during and after the 2016 election.

Joe diGenova is a former US attorney for the District of Columbia and he joins us tonight. So, Joe, just bottom line it, you know a lot about special counsels. Are you for this or no?

JOE DIGENOVA, ATTORNEY: Absolutely. It has to happen because the inspector general to whom this investigation has been given has no subpoena power, he has no authority to interview anybody outside the Department of Justice or FBI, he cannot even interview FBI and DOJ employees who have left.

He cannot interview Clapper, Brennan, any of the people associated with it. He can't interview all the people that have left, Yates, all those people.

So, the bottom line is, you have to have a grand jury. It's fascinating. We have a grand jury and a special counsel in Russiagate where there's been no crime committed and here, with the FISA violations, where there have been huge numbers of crimes committed by various people in various departments, we have no grand jury.

CARLSON: So, part of the reason you have a special counsel is to restore a public faith in the system itself. It seems to be making public the FISA request for the warrants would go a long way to ending the debate over all this. Can that happen? Will it happen?

DIGENOVA: It should happen. I cannot conceive of anything that is in those affidavits that would compromise sources and methods. It's ludicrous that they haven't been released. They should be released. The American people have a right to see them.

Because remember, Tucker, what this is all about, and FISA is just part of it, there was a brazen plot by senior officials at DOJ and FBI in the Obama administration and senior Obama administration intelligence officials to exonerate Hillary Clinton falsely and then to frame Donald Trump if Hillary lost the election.

We need a grand jury. We need the FISA applications out. We need it all done, and we need it done now.

CARLSON: So, here's a new angle in this and I want to get your response to it. So, FBI agent Peter Strzok, who still works at the bureau, I think, in human resources, may have known about a breach of Hillary Clinton's private e-mail server, but apparently didn't do anything about it.

Sources have told Fox News that, during the final months of the FBI's investigation into Hillary Clinton's server, irregularities in the server's metadata were found and that indicated a potential breach.

Strzok, who was overseeing that investigation, took no action in response, according to our sources. Maybe he was too busy sending anti-Trump text messages to his mistress or whatever.

Does that seem out of the ordinary to you?

DIGENOVA: It's absolutely out of the ordinary. And here's what happened on top of that. James Clapper, who was the director of national intelligence under Obama, when he found out that Hillary Clinton's server had been compromised, they're required by law to conduct a damage assessment, to see whether or not sources and methods have been compromised.

He refused. Clapper refused to do a damage assessment, and that is why Strzok decided not to investigate the compromise of Hillary's server.

CARLSON: On what grounds did Clapper, who by the way is the same one who under oath lied to Congress and the public about spying on Americans, on what grounds did he refuse to do a damage assessment?

DIGENOVA: Because he wanted to protect Hillary and he could do it and he had the consent of the president not to do an assessment.

And by that, I mean, the consent of President Obama.

CARLSON: Wow, that's pretty shocking. Thank you, Joe. I appreciate that.

DIGENOVA: Thank you, Tucker.

CARLSON: Well, a group of physicians are calling on doctors to shame gun owners during checkups. Kind of an amazing story. It may happen. Stay tuned.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CARLSON: Most cable new shows are pretty varied. They cover a lot of topics. But over on "MSNBC", Joy Reid's show is the exception. Her show has only one topic. How everyone who disagrees with her is a racist.

She's not a civil right advocate. She's just a monomaniac. Take a look.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOY REID, "MSNBC" HOST, "AM JOY": It's been no secret that Trump harbors racist attitudes about brown and black people in the US and other parts of the world.

We're just another Western nation falling to the ethno-nationalist forces sweeping across Europe, feeding on the fear of non-white and non-Christian immigrants.

Trump ushers in an emboldened KKK and an alt-right that will soon have a place in the White House.

We grapple with what it means to have a president stained by racism.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: Well, that's the whole show really every week. So, there's no need for you to watch, though you might be tempted.

But when you're Joy Reid, the answer to every question, no matter what it is, bigotry. The only variable is volume.

This past weekend, she melted down completely over a joke the president told about Nancy Pelosi. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REID: He reportedly also said that Nancy Pelosi has been trying to come up with a line as good as "lock her up" and that her line, says Donald Trump, that she announced last week is "mow the grass." Mow the freaking grass. That isn't going to stop MS-13. Mow the freakin' grass.

That sounds like an aspersion or a slap at immigrants, at Mexican- Americans. At least, that's how I'm reading it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: At least, that's how I'm reading it. Of course, you're reading it that way.

Of course, back in reality, Trump was just ridiculing Pelosi over a proposal that the boarder can be kept secure with proper lawn care.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NANCY PELOSI, HOUSE MINORITY LEADER: We all have a responsibility to protect our borders. Should there be fencing? Should there be technology? Should they mow the grass, so that people can't hide in it, let's talk about where a more serious structure might be necessary, where fencing will do or mowing grass, so people can't be smuggled through the grass.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: So, is Pelosi the secret grand wizard. We'll see if Joy Reid denounces her. Of course, she'll denounce us too. Can't wait.

Are you ready to get a gun control lecture next time you go to the doctor? Well, a recent editorial in the "Annals of Internal Medicine" urges physicians to start publicly campaigning for gun control, while also pestering their patients about how unsafe it is to own guns.

The editorial says "don't let your concerns for perceived political consequences get in the way for advocating for the well-being of your patients and the public."

Dr. Christine Laine is editor in chief of the "Annals of Internal Medicine" and she co-authored that piece and she joins us tonight. Doctor, thanks for coming on.

DR. CHRISTINE LAINE, PHYSICIAN: Thanks for having me, Tucker.

CARLSON: So, I was reading about this and you all said that, over at the annals, that the massacre in Las Vegas urged you to do this. And it got me thinking, would this have presented that? Do you think if you had told Stephen Paddock that guns are dangerous that he wouldn't have opened fire?

LAINE: No. And that's not exactly what our proposal is. Our proposal is to treat firearm injury like a public health problem that it has become. And one opportunity to do that is for in the exam rooms for doctors to talk to their patients who are at risk for injuring themselves or others with guns about how to deal with it more safely.

CARLSON: So, you're not an expert on guns. Would it make you uncomfortable if I gave you medical advice?

LAINE: Yes, that would make pretty uncomfortable.

CARLSON: Yes, me too. That's why I wouldn't do it.

LAINE: I'm not an expert on guns, but I am a medical expert. And part of what physicians do is to assess risk and then help talk to their patients about mitigating those risks.

CARLSON: Oh, assess risks. Like, when you guys send tens of millions of doses of opioids into Appalachia and killed over 100,000 people. That kind of risk. Where were you then? Just wondering. I can't help it since you bragged about your risk assessment abilities.

LAINE: Well, risk assessment - we do assess risk. And it wasn't doctors that sent tens of millions of doses of opioids to Appalachia or other places.

But we do assess risks. We assess risks of high blood pressure, smoking, risky sexual behavior that people puts at risk for infections. When people are elderly and at risk for falls, we ask about area rugs in the home. We talk to patients about seat belts. There are lots of different risks that we assess.

And this proposal is to remind physicians that when they have a patient who is at risk for harming themselves or others to ask about whether they have guns in the home and then talk to them about more safely storing those guns or other interventions that can make them and their families safer.

CARLSON: Would you acknowledge that there are people who ought to have a gun in the home? Like, if you live alone in a tough area where there's a lot of crime, home invasions, would you ever say it's probably better to have some way to defend yourself?

LAINE: As a physician, I would not. I don't think that that would be in my purview to do. It's certainly people's right in this country. But if that person was at risk of harming themselves or others, then I would be counseling them that maybe it would not be safe to have a gun in their home.

CARLSON: But what if they were at risk of being harmed? I mean, if the point of this is harm reduction, as you claimed it was, then if someone was a delivery man, for example, in a tough neighborhood delivering the newspaper or delivering to bodegas at 3:00 a.m. in the morning, wouldn't you say it's probably better to be armed?

LAINE: Actually, Tucker, there are data out there that show that if people have access to a gun in their home, it doesn't actually keep them safer. They're at much higher risk for a completed suicide or for a gun homicide. People that have guns in their home.

So, it's easy to say that your assumption that having a gun in your hope keeps your safer, there really are data that refute that assumption.

CARLSON: I don't think you know the data really because when you take suicide out of that, it's a totally different picture. And that's a separate question I'd love to ask you about, whether you're against suicide and trying to prevent suicide.

But let me just ask you, are you saying that there is no circumstance where someone is safer with a gun? Is that your medical position?

LAINE: No. What I was saying is that, in a systematic review published in the "Annals of Internal Medicine" that looked at 16 studies that evaluated the risk of a completed suicide or a gun homicide by whether or not the person had access to guns in the home that the risk for both those things, a completed suicide and a gun homicide, was higher in individuals -

CARLSON: I'm familiar with those statistics and they're misleading, so I'm a little surprised that you're citing them because I think serious people know that.

But let me just ask you this. if I said, I live at the end - I'm disabled and I live at the end of a long road where the police can't get there within ten minutes, there have been home invasions, I feel I need to protect myself, I feel I need a gun, would you actually say no, you don't need a gun? What would be your advice?

LAINE: I think that's the patient's choice. But if that patient was depressed and at risk for suicide or was having homicidal ideation or had cognitive deficits, I would probably counsel them that it was more safe for them not to have a gun than have a gun.

CARLSON: Well, I think that's fair. I mean, if you're worried the person is going to kill himself, I think you're absolutely right.

So, you as an organization have taken a strong position against suicide, it sounds like, is that right?

LAINE: Yes.

CARLSON: No. I mean, not all physicians have.

LAINE: I don't think there are too many physicians that are for suicide. I don't think there are too many physicians out there that advocate suicide, Tucker.

CARLSON: Well, I don't know, like the entire state of Oregon where it's legal and a lot of physicians participate in it and advocated for. So, yes, there are a lot of physicians in this country and in Europe who are for suicide, as you know.

LAINE: Tucker, you're talking about a completely different issue. You're talking about assisted suicide for people that have terminal illness and are at the end of their life. That really has nothing to do with the gun -

CARLSON: Well, I don't know, people shoot themselves with guns all the time when they're in terminal pain or facing a terminal illness. You're just saying suicide is OK with a physician, but not alone. Is that your position? I'm just trying to get to the nub of what you believe.

LAINE: I think suicide with a gun is always pretty messy and it's not something that physicians support.

And one of the things that's lost in this -

CARLSON: But suicide with a needle is OK.

LAINE: What?

CARLSON: Suicide with a needle can be OK, but suicide with a gun is always wrong because it's messy? Is that what you're saying?

LAINE: No, no. It's wrong because even physician-assisted suicide is not done with injection drugs. You're talking about euthanasia, which is not legal in this country.

CARLSON: OK. Well, you're dead at the end no matter what. So, it doesn't seem morally a different category to me. But, obviously, you disagree.

Dr. Laine, thanks for coming on.

LAINE: I thought we were going to talk about firearm injury?

CARLSON: Well, we were, but the majority, of course, of firearm deaths are suicides, as you said. And so, you're trying to protect people from that, again, as you said. So, I was trying to get to the nub of what you believe because I don't think it's enough to come on and spew platitudes. I think it's important to explain precisely what you believe and what you mean. So, I was trying to get you to do that.

LAINE: OK. So, if you give me an opportunity, I will. So, what this -

CARLSON: I think I have. Doctor, I think I've given you, I don't know, six or seven minutes. And I think you've had a chance to explain it. And I appreciate it. Thank you.

Well, the NRA says it's fed up with dishonest journalists and is warning them their time is running out. What does that mean? Dana Loesch joins us next. Stay tuned.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CARLSON: In a new advertisement, the National Rifle Association warns left wing journalists that "time is running out for them." Here it is.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DANA LOESCH, NRA SPOKESPERSON: To every lying member of the media, to every Hollywood phony, to the role model athletes who use their free speech to alter and undermine what our flag represents, to the politicians who would rather watch America burn than lose one ounce of their own personal power, to the late night hosts who think their opinions are the only opinions that matter, to the Joy-Ann Reids, the Morning Joes, the Mikas, to those who stain honest reporting with partisanship, to those who bring bias and propaganda to "CNN", "The Washington Post", and "The New York Times", your time is running out.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CARLSON: That's Dana Loesch. Of course, in the ad, she speaks for the NRA and she joins us tonight. Dana, thanks for coming on.

LOESCH: Thanks for having me, Tucker.

CARLSON: So, you are being criticized for inciting violence, some say, by that phrase "time is up." What does that mean?

LOESCH: Well, time's up, of course, is a play on the Time's Up movement, the Hollywood progressivism that, for so long, tolerated and celebrated people like Roman Polanski and Woody Allen and Harvey Weinstein.

But, also, at the very end of that video there, Tucker, it was an announcement for a program that I'm doing for "NRA TV" because I think a free people have the right to hold accountable and to frisk and fact check a free press. And so, that's what it's all about.

Now, to be clear, I don't believe in universal statements. And that's why, those people in the media and those people in Hollywood who are pushing propaganda or who are lying, yes, this is an indictment of you.

And the program for "NRA TV", which launches at the end of this month, Tucker, is focusing on media malpractice and holding accountable that media malpractice, which we have seen tons of, particularly in the past year.

CARLSON: Where do you think that comes from? Where do you think the gut level animist you see in the media toward NRA, toward gun owners, where does that come from?

LOESCH: I think it's just - honestly, I think that there are a lot of people who don't understand middle America. I think that they don't understand individuals who are Second Amendment practitioners.

I mean, you've talked about this on your show before, Tucker. And I edited under Andrew Breitbart big journalism for this very reason. I was entirely fed up with mainstream media, legacy media and the malpractice thereof.

And we saw how they disparaged and impugned the characters of those people, the members of the Tea Party. We saw them ignore, malign black conservatives. They ignore and malign conservative women. They ignore and malign gay conservatives.

And they bash good people in fly-over nation who are good enough to vote for the Clintons for how many years? But then, when they turn around and they vote for Donald Trump, suddenly, Tucker, those people become bigots and racists.

And we've watched media malign so many good Americans and seem to only report one side of the story.

I mean, for instance, just look at everything that's happened with Parkland. Where is the media focusing on the Broward sheriff, for instance, fighting the "Miami Herald" who has done epic work, they've done amazing work in this story?

They've filed a lawsuit against the Broward Sheriff's Office trying to get this video that the sheriff once promised that he was going to release. Where is the focus on that?

Or the political class that has let the mental crisis spiral out of control? Instead, honestly, Tucker, you know what they're writing about? They're writing about my musical taste in "Newsweek" and focusing on my appearance and me as a person and my husband and law-abiding gun owners across the United States instead of doing their due diligence and acting like the watchdog of the people.

So, who watches the watchers? That's the question.

CARLSON: If you're going to try and take people's guns away, don't you think you have a moral obligation - and prevent them from protecting themselves, don't you think you have an obligation to protect them better than our elites are now doing?

LOESCH: Yes. That's what I don't understand. Here we're looking at multiple systemic failures coming from the government that failed to protect us, all the while we have all of these individuals telling us, well, you can trust the government to protect you.

Well, really? They didn't with Sutherland Springs and they didn't with Garland, Texas and they didn't with San Bernardino and they didn't with the Navy Yard and they didn't in Charleston. I could go on and on because there were balls dropped in every single one of those instance, Tucker.

And the political class has been largely silent. They haven't been -

CARLSON: Of course.

LOESCH: They haven't been moved to make sure that the background check system works, like Wayne LaPierre has called for 25 years to do. And so, I mean, this is where the focus - that's where - honestly, that's where the focus should be in all of this.

CARLSON: Of course.

LOESCH: But to the point of people trying to say that somehow fact checking media is violent, the progressive left has been violent for a very long time. And I can't take seriously the criticisms of people, Tucker, who ignored the fires in Ferguson and they ignored Antifa violence and they ignored so many other things and now they want to act like it's threatening to fact check media.

CARLSON: I'm just laughing because if you're asking sincere questions about the people in charge, you're, obviously, working for Vladimir Putin. So, good luck with your new Russian masters, Dana.

LOESCH: I had Russian salad dressing earlier this week. So, I guess, I'm a spy or something.

CARLSON: It's unbelievable. Thank you for joining us. I appreciate it.

Facebook is moving forward with a new messaging app designed to get your children hooked on social media and rearrange their brains completely. Can anything stop big tech? We'll ask someone who is trying. Stay tuned.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CARLSON: 15 years ago, Facebook didn't exist. Today, it dominates our lives, shapes our conversation, even to some extent determines the way we think. Americans spend close to an hour every single day on Facebook. But the company wants more.

Facebook is rolling out a new app messenger for kids. It's aimed at children as young as six. More than 100 child developments experts have warned this is a bad idea. Could be a disaster. It serves to addict kids to social media earlier than ever.

It has massive implications for our society. The company seems to be ignoring that. Jim Steyer is CEO of Common Sense and wrote the book "Talking Back to Facebook" and he joins us tonight.

Jim, thanks for coming on. Have I mischaracterized what this app is intended to do and who it's aimed at?

JIM STEYER, COMMON SENSE MEDIA CEO: Nope. I think you nailed it, Tucker. I mean, really, this is about social media for the kindergarten set. It's basically getting hooked kids at younger and younger ages - 6, 7, 8 - on social media platforms like Facebook and it's crazy. We don't need it. And that's why all the experts came out and suggested that.

CARLSON: But we know that heavy social media use among young people leads to social maladjustment, depression, maybe even more grave things. I mean, the implication is certainly that it can really hurt people, gravely hurt them.

So, why would Facebook want to do this?

STEYER: Because it's in their own economic best interest. I mean, truthfully, you're trying to hook people at younger and younger ages to the brand and to the concept, and so it's an economic incentive. But, obviously, it's missing out on all the negative unintended consequences that you just referred to.

I mean, this is just a no-brainer for a parent. Why would you want your six-year-old using Facebook or Instagram? So, this is just - should be a non-starter for parents.

CARLSON: I mean, I'm sure R.J. Reynolds would like to come out with a new cigarette that's kindergarten friendly, but we say, no, you can't. I mean, adults can decide to do that if they want, but our society does not allow cigar makers to sell to children. Why are we allowing Facebook to do this when we know it harms them?

STEYER: Well, I think it's a very apt comparison. And it's like candy- coated cigarettes. So, you want to hook kids at younger and younger ages.

So, we actually at Common Sense think this is not a good idea at all. And it also brings up the broader issue of how do you get your kids - you're a parent too, Tucker. How do you get your kids away from the screen, enjoying the incredible outdoors and world around them? You just don't want sitting on social media platforms in kindergarten or actually at any age.

CARLSON: Yes. I mean, we know that it affects kids' ability to read and retain information and to think clearly. So, is there any legislative effort to pull back? Are we just passive in the face of a threat to our children?

STEYER: Actually, Tucker, there's a lot of good stuff coming on this kind of issue. There's stuff here on the West Coast in terms of looking at the addiction research that needs to be done around social media platforms.

You're seeing much greater privacy concern now. You're seeing a number of different legislative efforts to try to either encourage or require companies to respect the young kids in their audience. And that's going to grow.

We passed a bill called the Eraser Button here in California couple of years ago, so that kids who made dumb decisions could erase them. So, I think you're going to see a growing public outcry. And I think your covering it helps in that as well.

CARLSON: I hope so. I mean, I can just see them marketing Google Maps to babies to learn how to crawl. We're losing a lot in this. And, Jim, thank you for sounding the call about it. Appreciate it.

STEYER: Well, thank you for having us on, Tucker, and thanks for your supporting it as well. We like it.

CARLSON: Always. Well, we've got a major announcement about something starting tomorrow on the show. We'll tell you what it is coming up next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CARLSON: We hear a lot about female empowerment in this country and, of course, we're totally for that. We're for empowering all Americans.

But, for some reason, you almost never hear anything about how men are doing in America. So, we took a close look at the numbers. And we found them so shocking that we're devoting the month of March to a special series on men in America. Every Wednesday starting tomorrow, you'll be stunned by the scope of the crisis. We were. It's a largely ignored disaster. And it is a disaster. It affects every person in America.

Hope you'll be also heartened by some of the potential solutions we're looking at. We kick off tomorrow night with renowned psychologist and thinker Jordan Peterson every Wednesday at 8:00. I hope you'll joining us starting tomorrow.

Tune in every night to the show that is the sworn enemy of lying, pomposity, smugness and groupthink. Thanks for a great hour. Good night from Washington. Sean Hannity right now.

SEAN HANNITY, FOX NEWS HOST, "HANNITY": Lying, pomposity, smugness, groupthink, I got it. I totally got it.

CARLSON: That's the spirit, Sean.

Hannity: All right, Tucker. Thank you.

END
