urn:contentItem:5V83-PRR1-JCNX-329F-00000-00New Center Takes On Telecoms Over Robocall Epidemic2019-01-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:52ZLexisNexisNew Center Takes On Telecoms Over Robocall Epidemic

Link to Story

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22, 2019 /PRNewswire/ -- The New Center - an organization focused on creating the space for a political center in America - today released a new policy paper entitled "Robocalls: Big Telecom's Big Problem." Robocalling, the act of marketers or scammers sending automated voice messages to thousands of phones at once, has surged to epidemic levels. 48 billion calls robocalls were placed in the U.S. last year, an increase of 60%. "Many of these unwanted intrusions - with callers hawking everything from low interest loans and credit card debt forgiveness to vacations - are outrageous, and increasingly fraudulent," said New Center co-chair Bill Galston.

"These calls are a form of digital pollution; costing us time and money, violating our privacy, and degrading trust in the communications and technology networks upon which we increasingly depend. It is time for a new approach to dealing with this problem and that is precisely what The New Center is offering." An astounding half of all calls in the U.S. are expected to be robocall spam in 2019. The New Center has investigated the scale and causes of America's robocall epidemic and concluded that the current system for regulating robocalls just doesn't work. It's a system that relies on understaffed agencies like the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) to police an impossible number of illegal calls, creating an endless game of whack-a-mole that American consumers will lose every time. "It is time to fundamentally change the game. Telecom companies can and should step up to play a much greater role in solving the robocall problem, either voluntarily or with fines to drive their behavior," said Galston. "Telecom companies already have the technology to do it. Now, they just need the will." In November of last year, The New Center released a comprehensive policy paper on the influence of large tech companies on public discourse and American privacy. The robocall paper is an extension of this work, exploring yet another way in which unregulated and increasingly sophisticated technologies threaten the privacy and well-being of Americans. "Robocalls: Big Telecom's Big Problem" is available for download from newcenter.org. Newcenter.org is the home of all original content from The New Center, as well as curated stories highlighting bipartisan political efforts, original analysis of where the left and right overstep their bounds, and relevant and exclusive polling. Here is a brief summary of the policy solutions offered in the Robocall paper. A Dime for Every Robocall Telecom companies that refuse to police robocalls should pay a price. Congress and the FTC should work together to evaluate telecom carriers' robocall-blocking performance, and they should punish those that flounder. Fortunately, this evaluation infrastructure already exists. The FTC website's telemarketing complaint form asks several questions to assess whether reported calls are illegal, such as the time of the call, the amount of money requested, and the caller's company information. To punish carriers, the FTC should simply request the name of the carrier on the device that was illegally called. It can then fine carriers - a dime per call - for each illegal call reported on their networks. Considering there were 48 billion illegal robocalls in 2018, carriers could face as much as $4.8 billion in fines if they fail to step up to the plate. Although carriers should be incentivized through fines, the responsibility is not theirs alone. Government agencies must be tougher in cracking down on those responsible for illegal robocalls. Tougher Enforcement. Tougher Penalties. And Criminal Prosecutions American telecoms - with a push from Congress and the FTC - need to take the lead in policing robocalls. But government enforcement of robocallers that slip through the cracks can and should be a lot tougher. Suggested changes include:

The FCC and FTC should increase fines. In 2018, the agency fined illegal robocaller Adrian Abramovich $120 million for 97 million robocalls - a rate of about one dollar per call. While it's unknown exactly how much money Abramovich swindled from the victims of his vacation scams, FCC Chairman Ajit Pai did report that the ruse disrupted the operations of an emergency medical paging provider. By slowing down the network, Pai stated, Abramovich could have delayed vital emergency medical care.

The FTC should collect fines more swiftly. From 2013 to 2015, the FCC announced approximately $235 million in fines to communications firms — but as of November 2015, had collected $0. As of 2018, in fact, the FTC has only collected $121 million in fines — a fraction of the total fines levied. Slow and limited fine collection lets offenders off the hook and encourages others to try their hand at the illegal telemarketing trade.

The FTC should consider implementing criminal penalties on top of civil ones, as Connecticut did in 2018. Illegal robocalling businesses might think twice about their actions should they face time behind bars in addition to fines.

About The New Center American politics is broken, with the far left and far right making it increasingly impossible to govern. This will not change until a viable center emerges that can create an assertive agenda that appeals to the vast majority of the American people. This is the mission of The New Center, which aims to establish the intellectual basis for a viable political center in today's America. We create and promote ideas, news coverage, and commentary that helps people see common sense solutions to the problems we face. CONTACT SOURCE The New Center Related Links newcenter.org

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5BMD-4VX1-JBSS-S2F0-00000-00New chapter begins in net neutrality fight2014-02-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:53ZLexisNexisNew chapter begins in net neutrality fightBy James O'TooleNEW YORK (CNNMoney)

NEW YORK (CNNMoney) -- The battle for the open Internet has entered a new phase.

On one side, federal regulators and content providers are trying to preserve competition and keep all websites equally accessible. On the other, Internet service providers want to hold down their costs while keeping up with Americans' ever-increasing demand for digital content.

These goals may be mutually exclusive, and it isn't yet clear which side will emerge victorious.

The Federal Communications Commission faced a big setback on this front in January, when a court struck down its "Open Internet" rules. The FCC had barred ISPs from blocking or "unreasonably discriminating" against Web content, but Verizon successfully challenged the regulations on the grounds that the so-called "net neutrality" rules had overstepped the commission's legal authority.

The FCC now faces the challenge of crafting new net neutrality regulations that will withstand legal scrutiny. FCC Chairman Tom Wheeler said last week that the agency plans to do just that.

"Wheeler has stood up and walked through town like the sheriff and said, 'Okay, the rules are still on,'" said Tim Wu, a professor at Columbia Law School who coined the term "net neutrality."

"Whether he's shooting blanks or bullets isn't clear yet, but he's on the beat."

The FCC is currently collecting public comments before issuing its new set of regulations. Wheeler said those rules would prohibit ISPs from blocking websites, force them to disclose how they manage traffic and prevent them from favoring some kinds of traffic over others -- for example, loading Amazon faster than eBay. The agency also wants to enhance competition among ISPs by reversing restrictions on broadband services from local governments.

AT&T and Comcast have committed to abiding by the 2010 rules despite the January ruling that overturned them. Yet at the same time, they've instituted policies that some argue are against the spirit of net neutrality.

Comcast and Netflix announced an agreement Sunday in which the online video company will boost streaming speeds by paying for direct access to Comcast's broadband network, instead of delivering traffic through third parties as it's done previously.

Other big tech companies, including Microsoft, Google and Facebook already have paid-connection deals with big ISPs.

The FCC's pending rules won't address these kinds of deals, which could nonetheless affect the kinds of content consumers can access.

Given the massive amount of data consumption Netflix generates -- around a third of traffic on big ISPs during peak hours -- some analysts say it makes sense for the company to pay up. If ISPs have the option of charging content distributors, that could allow them to bring down costs for consumers and reinvest in infrastructure.

"Right now, I think most people are using the Internet without too many problems," said Rich Greenfield, an analyst with BTIG. "The question becomes whether this is a solution looking for a problem."

But consumer advocates worry that such direct-access agreements favor deep-pocketed content companies over small ones. They have also expressed concern that the FCC's planned rules won't cover the mobile Web, which is much more lightly regulated.

Last month, AT&T announced a "sponsored data" plan for mobile customers in which content from paying businesses won't count against monthly data caps, creating concerns about traffic discrimination. Verizon and AT&T have also previously blocked use of the Google Wallet app, which competes with their own offerings.

Though FCC doesn't have a great track record on net neutrality -- its two previous attempts at regulation having been invalidated by court rulings -- the agency does have a "nuclear option." The FCC could move ISPs into the same legal category as phone companies, which are treated more like utilities and face stricter regulations. The FCC hasn't taken the reclassification option off the table, but isn't pursuing it for the moment. The move would surely meet resistance from the industry's well-funded lobbyists, of which Wheeler was previously one.

Meanwhile, the biggest broadband providers could get even bigger: Comcast recently announced plans to buy Time Warner Cable for $45 billion, potentially creating a combined company that would bring cable or Internet service to about 30% of American subscribers.

"When it comes to high-speed Internet access, you have a few massive players with unconstrained market power, and as a country, we're risking our future by not treating Internet access like a utility," said Susan Crawford, a professor at Cardozo Law School. "Instead we're serving the shareholders of the cable companies."

The agency also wants to enhance competition among ISPs by reversing restrictions on broadband services from local governments.

AT&T and Comcast have committed to abiding by the 2010 rules despite the January ruling that overturned them. Yet at the same time, they've instituted policies that some argue are against the spirit of net neutrality.

Comcast and Netflix announced an agreement Sunday in which the online video company will boost streaming speeds by paying for direct access to Comcast's broadband network, instead of delivering traffic through third parties as it's done previously.

Related: Customers react to Comcast-TWC deal

Other big tech companies, including Microsoft, Google and Facebook already have paid-connection deals with big ISPs.

The FCC's pending rules won't address these kinds of deals, which could nonetheless affect the kinds of content consumers can access.

Given the massive amount of data consumption Netflix generates -- around a third of traffic on big ISPs during peak hours -- some analysts say it makes sense for the company to pay up. If ISPs have the option of charging content distributors, that could allow them to bring down costs for consumers and reinvest in infrastructure.

"Right now, I think most people are using the Internet without too many problems," said Rich Greenfield, an analyst with BTIG. "The question becomes whether this is a solution looking for a problem."

But consumer advocates worry that such direct-access agreements favor deep-pocketed content companies over small ones. They have also expressed concern that the FCC's planned rules won't cover the mobile Web, which is much more lightly regulated.

Last month, AT&T announced a "sponsored data" plan for mobile customers in which content from paying businesses won't count against monthly data caps, creating concerns about traffic discrimination. Verizon and AT&T have also previously blocked use of the Google Wallet app, which competes with their own offerings.

Though FCC doesn't have a great track record on net neutrality -- its two previous attempts at regulation having been invalidated by court rulings -- the agency does have a "nuclear option." The FCC could move ISPs into the same legal category as phone companies, which are treated more like utilities and face stricter regulations. The FCC hasn't taken the reclassification option off the table, but isn't pursuing it for the moment. The move would surely meet resistance from the industry's well-funded lobbyists, of which Wheeler was previously one.

Meanwhile, the biggest broadband providers could get even bigger: Comcast recently announced plans to buy Time Warner Cable for $45 billion, potentially creating a combined company that would bring cable or Internet service to about 30% of American subscribers.

"When it comes to high-speed Internet access, you have a few massive players with unconstrained market power, and as a country, we're risking our future by not treating Internet access like a utility," said Susan Crawford, a professor at Cardozo Law School. "Instead we're serving the shareholders of the cable companies."

urn:contentItem:5VFN-MK31-JCBW-N2J1-00000-00'New code' to crack down on net giants2019-02-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:53ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9'New code' to crack down on net giantsMacer Hall

INTERNET giants should abide by an official code of conduct to stamp out the spread of "disinformation", senior MPs have said.

They claimed democracy was at risk from the "malicious and relentless" bombardment of "fake news" faced by internet users, including "dark adverts from unidentifiable sources".

And they called for a compulsory ethics code, enforced by a powerful independent watchdog with the power to launch legal proceedings and slap fines on offending technology firms.

MPs on the Digital Culture, Media and Sport Committee said in a report: "Social media companies cannot hide behind the claim of being merely a platform and maintain that they have no responsibility themselves in regulating the content of their sites."

Tory MP and committee chairman Damian Collins said: "Democracy is at risk from the malicious and relentless targeting of citizens with disinformation and personalised dark adverts from unidentifiable sources, delivered through the major social media platforms we use every day.

"Much of this is directed from agencies working in foreign countries, including Russia.

"Big tech companies are failing in the duty of care they owe to their users to act against harmful content and to respect their data privacy rights.

"Companies like Facebook exercise massive market power which enables them to make money by bullying the smaller technology companies and developers who rely on this platform to reach their customers.

"These are issues that the major tech companies are well aware of, yet continually fail to address. We need a radical shift in the balance of power between the platforms and the people. The age of inadequate self-regulation must come to an end.

"The rights of the citizen need to be established in statute, by requiring the tech companies to adhere to a code of conduct written into law by Parliament, and overseen by an independent regulator."

Culture Secretary Jeremy Wright yesterday vowed to look at "all possible options for penalties" in a forthcoming White Paper outlining proposals for curbing wrongdoing on the internet.

OPINION: PAGE 12

Penalties...Jeremy Wright

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5W9V-F3S1-F03R-N1VK-00000-00New Commissioner of Competition Increases Focus on the Digital Economy2019-06-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:52ZLexisNexisNew Commissioner of Competition Increases Focus on the Digital Economy

Jun 11, 2019( Canadian Competition ...gulatory Law: http://www.ipvancouverblog.com/ Delivered by Newstex) June 11, 2019 Practical Law Canada has published a New Legal Update, which discusses recent Competition Bureau (Bureau) and policy changes relating to the digital economy in Canada.This new Update includes key points from recent Commissioner of Competition speeches, media interviews and conferences hosted by the Bureau and OECD. Below is an excerpt with a link to the full Update.____________________ On March 5, 2019, the Government of Canada announced that Matthew Boswell would serve as Canada's new Commissioner of Competition (Commissioner) for a five-year term. Shortly after his appointment, the new Commissioner outlined his policy and enforcement priorities in a speech at the Canadian Bar Association's Competition Law Spring Conference (seeCommissioner of Competition, Speech, No River too Wide, No Mountain too High: Enforcing and Promoting Competition in the Digital Age[1](May 7, 2019)). Many of the new Commissioner's stated priorities for the Competition Bureau (Bureau) are focused on the digital economy.

The Commissioner's initial digital economy related comments in his May 7th speech, including enhanced enforcement, have now been amplified in subsequent announcements and proceedings (see, for example,CBC News, New tools, stiffer penalties needed to police big tech companies, says competition watchdog (May 31, 2019)[2]andOECD Conference on Competition and the Digital Economy (June 3, 2019)[3]). The Bureau also hosted a Data Forum in Ottawa on May 20th, which included discussions by Canadian and international experts on a range of digital economy related issues, including digital platforms, privacy and competition, data portability and interoperability and the regulatory and enforcement landscape. The Bureau's increased emphasis on competition and the digital economy tie in to current Federal Government related policies, notably its recently releasedDigital Charter[4], which includes several competition related principles (for example, stronger enforcement, ensuring a level playing field including fair competition and transparency, portability and interoperability to give Canadians more control over their data). The Bureau's new digital economy policy goals also come at the same time as US antitrust agencies are reported to be commencing investigations of Google, Facebook and Amazon and a parallel House Judiciary Committee inquiry has been launched into whether tech companies are using their market power to harm competition. () For the full Update, see: New Commissioner of Competition Increases Focus on the Digital Economy[5]. SERVICES AND CONTACT I am a Toronto competition and advertising lawyer offering business and individual clients efficient and strategic advice in relation to competition/antitrust, advertising, Internet and new media law and contest law. I also offer competition and regulatory law compliance, education and policy services to companies, trade and professional associations and government agencies. My experience includes advising clients in Toronto, Canada and the US on the application of Canadian competition and regulatory laws and I have worked on hundreds of domestic and cross-border competition, advertising and marketing, promotional contest (sweepstakes), conspiracy (cartel), abuse of dominance, compliance, refusal to deal, pricing and distribution, Investment Canada Act and merger matters. For more information about my competition and advertising law services see:competition law services[6]. To contact me about a potential legal matter see:contact[7] For more regulatorylaw updates follow me on Twitter:@CanadaAttorney[8] [ 1]: https://www.canada.ca/en/competition-bureau/news/2019/05/no-river-too-wide-no-mountain-too-high-enforcing-and-promoting-competition-in-the-digital-age.html [ 2]:   https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/digital-economy-regulation-competition-1.5156743 [ 3]:   https://oecd.streamakaci.com/ccde2019/ [ 4]:   https://www.ic.gc.ca/eic/site/062.nsf/eng/h_00108.html [ 5]:   https://ca.practicallaw.thomsonreuters.com/Document/I7dd23f248b9111e9adfea82903531a62/View/FullText.html?productData=categoryPageUrl%3AHome%2FPracticeAreas%2FCompetition...nsitionType=CategoryPageItem...textData=(sc.Default) [ 6]:   http://www.ipvancouverblog.com/competitionlawservices/canadiancompetitionlawservices/ [ 7]:   http://www.ipvancouverblog.com/contact/ [ 8]:   https://twitter.com/Canadaattorney

urn:contentItem:5XPT-MVM1-JB5M-W09W-00000-00New Competitive Threats Pressure Banks in North America to Respond to Changing Customer Demands, Reveals Study by the Economist Intelligence Unit Released by Temenos2019-12-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:52ZLexisNexisNew Competitive Threats Pressure Banks in North America to Respond to Changing Customer Demands, Reveals Study by the Economist Intelligence Unit Released by Temenos

AUSTIN, Texas, Dec. 10 -- Temenos issued the following news release:

- Nearly a third (33%) of North American bankers are feeling pressure from the changing competitive environment, compared to 28% globally

- 34% of North American bankers struggle to keep up with changing customer behavior and demands

- 40% of bankers in North America see new technologies as trend having the highest impact on the banking sector

- Launching an open banking strategy in the next five years is a top priority for 37% of respondents

North American bankers sense danger more than most from new entrants to their market, according to a global retail banking survey released by Temenos (SIX: TEMN), the banking software company. The Economist Intelligence Unit (EIU) report, A Whole New World: How technology is driving the evolution of intelligent banking in North America, conducted on behalf of Temenos, reveals changing customer behavior and demands as one of the biggest trends that will impact retail banking in North America.

The study also found that banking clients increasingly seek speed and convenience, and with Google the latest tech giant to announce plans for "smart" checking accounts linked to the Google Pay app, new technologies are understandably seen as high impact trends on the sector for both the short (40% for 2020) and medium terms (43% for 2025).

In addition, the study shows challenger banks are increasingly making their presence felt in North America, be they domestic start-ups such as Chime or Simple (now part of BBVA), or overseas brands such as Monzo and Revolut expanding their footprint.

However, the study reveals that payment players, such as PayPal, Apple Pay, Visa, and Square, are seen as a far greater immediate competitive challenge (cited by 41% of respondents for 2020), than the neo-banks (16% for 2020). Banks are also conscious of the upcoming threat posed by big tech firms teaming up with fintechs to create hybrids (29% for 2025), where the app provider has no need for a banking license and is not required to comply with regulatory capital ratios.

Thomas E. Hogan, President of Temenos North America, said:

* "Banks and credit unions are under enormous pressure to transform and disrupt. This is not new news and has been in flight for the past several years. The key insight today is to swiftly shift from the legacy focus on survival and efficiency to a focus on growth and leadership. There is an immediate opportunity to leverage technology for growth in clients, assets, lending, loyalty, and human capital. It is equally important that financial institutions pursue these outcomes in parallel with the enablement of open banking."

Other Key Findings

* North American banks are focusing their actions on becoming digital eco-systems, offering bank-related and non-financial services from third parties (44%), with only few attempting to build niche propositions (16%) or opting to become a third-party aggregator (12%)

* The primary need for North American banks is to be far more agile (38% for 2020) and able to bring new features and products to market, but that is complicated when regulatory requirements* have not been set

* With a plurality of North American banks planning an open banking strategy (37% for 2025), the need for greater regulatory clarity will only become more pressing

* Although tech firms may be more than capable of launching new services that fully replicate the banking experience, they appear to be holding back. North American respondents are the least likely to agree that sandbox collaboration between banks and fintechs will be mainstream by 2025 (48% vs. 56% globally)

Source: Temenos

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:60FP-F0G1-JB20-G241-00000-00New COVID-19 Stimulus; Interview with Rep. Guy Reschenthaler (R-PA); "Capital War": Ray Dalio on How China Tensions Affect U.S. Dollar; Potential Sunscreen Risks; Texas Wins Tesla: Elon Musk to Build $1 Billion Tesla Plant Near Austin; WSJ: Google to Keep Employees at Home Until July 2021 Due to Pandemic.2020-07-27T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:52ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTGuy Reschenthaler, Scott Wren; Mitch Roschelle, John Lonski, Leland Miller, Lee Carter, Janette NesheiwatNEWSFinancial072703cb.231New COVID-19 Stimulus; Interview with Rep. Guy Reschenthaler (R-PA); "Capital War": Ray Dalio on How China Tensions Affect U.S. Dollar; Potential Sunscreen Risks; Texas Wins Tesla: Elon Musk to Build $1 Billion Tesla Plant Near Austin; WSJ: Google to Keep Employees at Home Until July 2021 Due to Pandemic.Dagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone, Stuart Varney

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning.

I'm Dagen McDowell, in for Maria Bartiromo. It is Monday, July 27th.

You're top stories at 8:00 a.m. Eastern on the nose.

More stimulus ahead. Republicans set to announce their latest relief plan with a $1 trillion price tag.

Search for coronavirus vaccine. Shares of Moderna surging premarket after announcing the start of its phase three clinical trial. Up 8 percent in premarket trading.

Unrest in America. Another weekend of violent protests. Portland, Seattle, now Oakland, among the cities seeing dangerous clashes.

Rising tensions with China. The U.S. Consulate in Chengdu shut down. China taking over that property.

Plus a warning on seeds. People are receiving mysterious packages of seeds in the mail, believed to be from China. State officials are telling people not to plant them.

Wow.

Earnings season kicking into high gear. One dozen Dow components reporting this week including Pfizer, McDonald's, Boeing, Apple and ExxonMobil. We'll also hear from Facebook, Amazon, and Google parent Alphabet what to look for and what we can expect.

Turning to futures this morning. Up to the plus side 126-point gain on the Dow futures, holding steady with that triple digit gain, gains across the board there.

The tax flight. Joe Rogan joining the list of people leaving California heading to that Lone Star state. That photo is probably 25 years old. Joe Rogan still looks good, though.

MORNINGS WITH MARIA is live right now.

Checking global market action.

In Europe markets are mixed. It's been the case all morning, our morning. Moving into the trading day, losses -- slight losses in England and France.

In Asia overnight market also mixed. China reported that June industrial profits surged 11.5 percent from a year ago. These numbers, of course, put out by the Communist Party. Gains in South Korea and Shanghai this morning.

Joining the conversation this morning, all morning: Lee Carter, John Lonski and Mitch Roschelle.

Let's move on to Republican lawmakers and the White House set to release their coronavirus stimulus today.

Cheryl Casone has some details, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: That is right. Good morning again, Dagen.

That $1 trillion package from Senate Republicans includes more stimulus checks $1,200 dollar direct payments to many Americans, along with a proposal to reduce unemployment benefits to 70 percent of income. The relief bill not expected to extended the $600 dollar enhanced unemployment benefits which is expiring July 31.

This also would exclude a payroll tax cut, something President Trump wanted but Democrats and some Republicans have opposed.

Unrest in America. In Seattle officers clashing with protesters outside a police precinct just one day after it was damaged by explosives.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: (EXPLETIVE DELETED)

(EXPLETIVE DELETED)

(EXPLETIVE DELETED)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: The Seattle police department releasing officer body cam video of those attacks. Nearly 60 officers were injured during the protests on Saturday, 47 people were arrested.

Meanwhile, in Portland protests stretched out into their 60th straight night. Protesters set off fireworks overnight near the courthouse. Police had to use tear gas to disperse those crowds. Two people were taken in custody after opening fire just one block from the demonstrations. One person was hurt there.

We're taking a look at shares of Moderna this morning. It is rallying big time, up almost 8 percent. The company announced its starting phase three of its coronavirus vaccine trials, after it received another $472 million from the U.S. Government.

Moderna previously received more than $83 million in funding. This study expected to enroll 30,000 participants here in the United States. The main goal: preventing the symptomatic COVID-19 disease from ever taking hold on someone.

Stock is up almost 8.5 percent.

Well, today the body of Congressman John Lewis will arrive in Washington. He is going to go lie in state in the Capitol Rotunda tonight and tomorrow.

Lewis was given the same honor in Alabama's capitol building yesterday. His flag-draped casket arriving there after this power night that happened in Selma. A horse-drawn caisson taking Lewis across the Edmund Pettus Bridge for the final crossing. He's going to be laid to rest in Georgia on Thursday,

Well switching gears, let's talk about the weather.

Hanna has been downgraded no to a tropical storm after making landfall as a category one hurricane. This was the first hurricane for the 2020 Atlantic season. National Weather Service says the system unloaded more than 12 inches of rain in some parts of Texas.

Meanwhile, in the Pacific, Hurricane Douglas took a swipe at Hawaii, coming within a very thin distance of a direct hit there. But that hasn't stopped heavy rain and winds from battering part of Maui. President Trump issued an emergency declaration for the state.

And those are all your headlines this morning, Dagen. Back over to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Cheryl.

Republican lawmakers set to unveil their next coronavirus stimulus plan today, later today. The proposal expected to cost about $1 trillion. It would include liability protection for businesses, another $1,200 in payments to Americans, money for additional testing, as well as $100 billion going to schools and universities.

Joining us now, Pennsylvania congressman, member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee and House Judiciary Committee, Guy Reschenthaler.

Congressman, great to see you.

But what about that $600 extra that people are receiving every week in jobless benefits? That is the sticking point. Are you going to leave Americans without any extra money?

REP. GUY RESCHENTHALER (R-PA): Dagen, first off, thanks for having me on. I appreciate it.

Let's just talk about that extra $600 a week in payments. That's really a drag on the economy, because what it is doing is it's incentivizing people not to go back to work. And those that are going back to work, employers are finding themselves having to pay well over fair market wages to incentivize folks to come back to work. So that is dragging the economy down.

The plan that's going to be unveiled today is going to provide 70 percent of what somebody would make if they were going back to work. So if the individual wants that extra 30 percent, they're going to have to go back to work. So I'm supportive of that. And of course, there is direct stimulus payments to individuals, that is outside of the unemployment compensation.

So I think it's a good starting point. We also have money going to schools, and individuals, parents who have choice to take a voucher and be able to send their children -- their kids to schools that are open, which will incentivize schools to open and open safely.

So I think it's a good starting point. It's $1 trillion. The far left social justice Democrats want to have $4 trillion dollars in spending. So let's see where this goes.

MCDOWELL: Well, respectfully, the Republicans, you guys and gals, waited so long, though, that this $600 per week, even if it's cut to 70 percent of what you would be making on the job -- you waited so long, that these benefits are probably going to disappear for literally millions of Americans. The Democrats will tell you that they passed a 3.5 -- this is in the House -- a $3.5 trillion bill, additional stimulus that passed in the House in May. What took you so long?

RESCHENTHALER: Well, I would say that bill that the Democrats passed in May, that was passed pretty much along party lines, was nothing more than a messaging bill. It was crammed with a bunch of far left radical ideas. It was a way for the Democrats to take advantage of this situation, this pandemic, and cram in their Green New Deal provisions, their really far left socialists ideals were crammed into that --

(CROSSTALK)

MCDOWELL: I didn't say that you should take -- I didn't say that the Republicans should take it up and get behind it.

But again, you knew that these - this $600 per week was expiring at the end of this month. Those benefits disappeared over the weekend in many states. So where were you in June and most of July?

RESCHENTHALER: Well, we were trying to get the Democrats to come to a reasonable position, but Nancy Pelosi is the speaker of the House, not Kevin McCarthy. If Kevin McCarthy were speaker, we would have had something reasonable.

But -- call me an old school Republican, Dagen, but I still think the best way that you get the economy back on track is reducing taxation, reducing regulation. That reduces the burden on businesses, and it incentivizes business to grow, hire more people, and get back on track.

You can't get this economy back by not having tax cuts and by throwing regulation -- more regulation on business. That is why the Republican plan, which provides for liability protections, is a good starting place. I would like to see payroll tax cuts or holidays. I would like to see reduction in corporate income tax, in personal income tax as well. But unfortunately, we've got to negotiate with these far left Democrats that control the House of Representatives.

MCDOWELL: I'm not getting behind trillions of dollars in additional spending, and I fully acknowledge that roughly - well more than two-thirds, based on University of Chicago research -- more than two-thirds of individuals who were collecting unemployment benefits are receiving more in unemployment than they received on the job. I acknowledge that.

But -- but again, where were the Republicans in the Senate that really needed to craft something, in order to provide some certainty for the American individual? Families who can't go back to work, because their economy is still potentially shut down in some way because of this virus.

Maria -- speaking of the Senate, Maria Bartiromo talked to Senator Lindsey Graham on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES" who had this to say about support for COVID-19 relief.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: So are we going to see you pass something before the Senate leaves on August 8th? What is the conversation now about those unemployment benefits which will go away on July 31?

SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R-SC): Half the Republicans are going to vote no to any phase four package, that's just a fact. And a lot of Democrats are going to insist on $3 trillion, which would be way too much. It would be wasted money.

I'm confident President Trump will lead us to a solution where we have money for kids, jobs, and healthcare. We need to stimulate the economy. We need a phase four, and I think we will come together before August the 5th to get this done.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Congressman, reaction to that?

RESCHENTHALER: Well, I think Lindsey Graham is right. But a lot of people are hesitant to vote for another $4 trillion -- for $4 trillion more, because at the end of the day, this debt that we are carrying, it is a tax on future generations. It is also going to inhibit growth moving forward.

So before we spend $4 trillion, let's see if we can get away with spending $1 trillion. But let's also make sure that schools are safely reopening, so when the jobs come back open, parents feel comfortable leaving. They won't have to stay home with their kids. Let's make sure that we get some kind of voucher system in place. And let's also make sure that we have liability protections, so that these businesses are not facing lawsuits for reopening.

So there is a lot going on right now. It is complex. But at the end of the day, we've got to incentivize that -- we've got to incentivize businesses to reopen. And again, I'd push for tax cuts and at least a break on the payroll tax cut. Unfortunately -- payroll taxes -- unfortunately, that has been taken off the table already.

MCDOWELL: It has been.

Congressman good to see you. Guy Reschenthaler, thanks for being here this Monday.

RESCHENTHALER: Thank you, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Coming up China Beige Book CEO Leland Miller weighing in on the rising tensions with China as the U.S. consulate in Chengdu officially closes.

And keeping safe this summer. The new warning over the chemicals found in sunscreen -- sunscreen.

Plus treat your heart, treat your heart. The new study that shows how eating chocolate can lower your risk of heart disease.

You're watching MORNINGS WITH MARIA live on Fox Business.

MCDOWELL: Futures are pointing to gains this morning. Triple-digit gain on the Dow futures, 120 points to -- 24 points to the plus side on the Dow. This ahead of a big earnings week and economic data. One dozen Dow components will report this week. Some of the major companies: Pfizer, Mickey D's, Boeing, Apple, Exxon.

Joining me now, Wells Fargo senior global market strategist Scott Wren.

Scott, what are you watching this week? Is it earnings? Is it what these companies are saying about investment, hiring the road ahead?

SCOTT WREN, WELLS FARGO SENIOR GLOBAL MARKET STRATEGIST: Well, Dagen, I think, you know, earnings season remember actual range (ph) results are what happened in the past. So we want to try to look forward. Normally you get some guidance out of these but as we know. A lot of the S&P 500 companies have pulled guidance and really for the most part, the other ones that are giving you a little guidance are being very conservative.

So I'm not so sure that we're getting a lot of valuable information from the guidance either. So earnings, you know, it is -- it is meaningful as always but hey we know it's going to be bad news. The market's expecting 40, 45 percent down. It's a little bit better than that right now.

But I'm not expecting a whole heck of a lot of -- guidance out of what we're seeing here. Really this week, there is a couple of things. I mean I'm interested to see what GDP is going to be really, and you know, the orders for durable goods. You know, that's always a good gauge of business capital spending. We're not expecting a whole lot of that but it would be nice to have a little bit.

But I think that GDP number is really going to grab the attention, the expectations are so wide out there we are looking for minus 29 percent. I think that is a little bit better than the consensus but, you know, you're seeing anything from, you know, minus 20 to minus 45 out there for the range.

So there is a lot going on this week, and I think the markets probably going to be a little bit volatile. But all in all, you know, this virus news is the most important as we look ahead.

MCDOWELL: John Lonski, jump in here.

JOHN LONSKI, CHIEF ECONOMIST, MOODY'S ANALYTICS: Well, let's get to the point. Do you think the market right now is grossly overvalued, fairly valued? Would you buy or hold?

WREN: Well, you know, John, for us for right here 32.50 is our year-end target S&P 500. So it's pretty fair value for us. Maybe a little bit ahead of itself, as we look out through year-end 2021. We've got a 3,500 number out there. So, for us, you know we want to be in this. We think we are going to have some opportunities to buy at lower levels because really if you look at retail investors in general they have a lot of cash.

They have missed a lot really in the last 10 years. And they've certainly missed a lot of this big bounce that we've had off the March 23rd low. So that's what we're trying to encourage our clients to do on big down weeks and big down days. You need to have a plan. You need to step in. You need to look at tech, consumer discretionary, communications services, health care -- those types of sectors. And I think those are the ones that likely to carry us forward as we recover in 2021.

MCDOWELL: I love gold, the smell of it, the taste of it.

That is "Goldmember", by the way. I don't love gold but clearly people do, Scott. It's hitting their all-time high, record high near $2,000 an ounce. What do you -- what is your take?

WREN: Well I can tell you that our commodities guys have been on this thing and they've been right. And you know, I'm not a gold expert at all but this is a touch above where we thought it was going to finish the year. But if we look out through 2021 -- and that is what we're trying to give our clients, a longer view rather than what is happening over the next six months because anything can happen really.

But over the next year and a half, our commodities group is looking for $2,200 to $2,300 in gold. So they're bullish on it. I think it's probably jumped a little bit quicker than what we expected but the pricing in here is not a surprise overall but you know, let's face it. The overnight move, you get a big move like this in one day, doesn't happen often in gold. But clearly this is a momentum story.

MCDOWELL: Scott, great to see you. Thank you so much.

WREN: Thanks, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Scott Wren, take care.

Coming up unrest in America, Portland chaos stretches into day 60. We look -- that is coming up ahead.

Plus fleeing a high-tax blue state. Why Joe Rogan is sitting his sights on Texas.

BARTIROMO: This week on MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

Tomorrow, Joe Biden puts his top campaign surrogate to work. Former Obama adviser Valerie Jarrett is here.

Wednesday, Mark Meadows expecting the Durham probe indictment soon. Rudy Giuliani on who is sweating this out.

And Thursday, with the conventions just weeks away Sarah Sanders, lays out Trump's path to victory.

On Friday we are following your money with "The Word on Wall Street" and Blackrock's Rick Rieder.

It's all right here on MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

MCDOWELL: The gym owners who defied New Jersey's lockdown orders had been arrested. Their lawyer telling Fox News the Bellmawr police blocked the Atilis Gym parking lot this morning. Ian Smith and Frank Trombetti (ph) were arrested a short time later. They join "FOX AND FRIENDS" on Saturday after a judge ruled that the state can close their gym. Their lawyers say they're expected to get a complaint and be released this morning.

We've reached out the Bellmawr police for comment.

Now, unrest in Seattle. Officers blocking protesters from a police precinct. The demonstrations were mainly peaceful, much different scene than one day before.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(EXPLETIVE DELETED) (EXPLETIVE DELETED) (EXPLETIVE DELETED).

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Seattle police releasing body camera video of Saturday's riots. Police say they were hit by rocks, water bottles, explosives. 59 officers injured; 47 people were arrested.

Lee, I think that we have to stop calling these protests. These are an anarchic -- they're riots by anarchists. These are criminals. And why more people aren't being arrested I have no idea.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKI AND PARTNERS: You know, I think it's a really important distinction because police officials in both Portland and Seattle made that same distinction. They said these are not protests. These are riots. They classify them as riots and I think it's important to understand that shift.

Because when you oppose -- protest that's one thing. When you're opposing riots it's a very different thing. And I think the language is very important that it's used properly here. And this is a really, really bad state of affairs. This isn't about, you know, left versus right or about being political. This is really about the truth of what we're seeing there.

MCDOWELL: But these mayors and they are Democratic-run cities,. Mitch, that they are again, if they're anti-Trump they seem to get a pass from people on the left.

MITCH ROSCHELLE, PWC PARTNERS: Yes. but the images aren't necessarily the same when you go from newspaper to newspaper or cable news network to cable news network. And I think Lee is absolutely right. I said they are what they are and they are riots and they are violent and there are bad people here.

And I think the electorate really needs to know the truth about what is going on.

MCDOWELL: Why aren't these companies, these large corporations that are based in say a Seattle like a Starbucks, a Microsoft outside of Seattle. Amazon -- why aren't these CEOs and leaders there getting on the horn and call and say put a stop to this. We're not going to sit by and watch businesses being destroyed and a local economy being decimated. And watch people get injured in the streets.

Where are you? Why don't they do that? Oh that is right they don't want to get in the middle of politics.

Coming up China Beige Book CEO Leland Miller here to talk about the growing threat of China. What we're doing about it. The U.S. consulate in Chengdu being closed.

Plus futures are pointing to gains at the open.

June durable goods orders out in just moments.

Stay with us.

MCDOWELL: Welcome back I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, July 27th. We're waiting on June durable goods orders. Economists expecting a 7.2 percent gain from May. We have the numbers as soon as they hit the tape. 114-point gain on the Dow Futures right now. Ex- transportation, we're also expecting to see a gain. Cheryl, take it away.

CASONE: All right. Let's go through these numbers. First are the durable goods number month-over-month. The expectation was a gain of 7.2 percent. Slight beat here, 7.3 percent. This nowhere near the previous number that we'd gotten that was 15.7 percent. That was really about pent up demand from the shutdown of the U.S. economy.

If you strip out transportation, if you trip up the transports, air airplanes and things like that - trains, you get gain of 3.3 percent. That is to the upside. That's a little bit below the estimate of 3.5 percent. Anyway, so that is a little bit below what we were expecting there.

If you look at general machine orders, up to 2.7 percent; electrical equipment, up a gain of 1.2 percent; defense and aircraft parts, that's a big loss. That's interesting. That's a that's a strip out of 30.6 percent. That's actually a down side number.

But, again - so we're getting - we're pretty much steady on the Dow right now. But this is basically the pretty much in line with expectations, Dagen. So that's the breaking news on the U.S. economy.

One more thing I do want to look at before I send it back to you Dagen, and that's core capital goods month-over-month. That was better than expected. The gain was 3.3 percent. The expectation was 2.3 percent. So really, it's just - if you take out the transports that was the slight miss that we got. Back to you.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much, Cheryl. This is two straight months of durable goods orders increase after manufacturers, of course, ramping up production after the shutdowns. John, your reaction to this.

LONSKI: Well, I focused on that better than expected reading on core capital goods orders, that tells us that perhaps a capital spending, business investment spending is at the start of a recovery.

And, by the way, I think CapEx has fared much better during the COVID-19 recession, compared to what happened during the Great Recession. That by itself brings attention to how this current recession is very different from past recessions and that the service sector is suffering the most far more than manufacturing is.

MCDOWELL: Mitch, your reaction.

ROSCHELLE: Yes, I'm with John. I think, buried in all of this, in a good way, could be a revival of manufacturing. I think a lot of companies realized how vulnerable their supply chain was not just to China, but to other parts of the world. And I think as we begin to manufacture and assemble back here at home, I think you're going to see more and more investment in capital goods in order to enable that. So I think there's a nice silver lining here and these numbers even though they were slightly above or below expectations.

MCDOWELL: Thank you so much guys. Meantime, consulate turnover. U.S. officials clearing out of the Consulate General in Chengdu, China, after having Chinese officials do the same in Houston, Texas last week as tensions rise between Beijing and Washington.

Meantime, Chinese researcher, one was arrested by U.S. authorities, who was hiding out in China's San Francisco Consulate after allegedly lying to investigators about her Chinese military service. Her hearing is today. Joining me now China Beige Book CEO, Leland Miller. Leland, certainly, tensions worsening. Where do we go from here?

LELAND MILLER, CEO, CHINA BEIGE BOOK: Well, believe it or not, we're in the middle of a bit of a calm in the relationship. So things sound nasty. You've got a lot of rhetoric going back and forth between the two sides, but there hasn't anything on either side, including the consulate shutdowns that has escalated to the next step.

And I think part of that's because both sides have been focused on the pandemic and the economic recovery associated with the pandemic. I think that this is about the change. And it's about the change probably as soon as next month.

The phase one trade deal I think is in real trouble right now. You have a situation where if you lose that and you start moving into the fall, and you move into the run up to the election, which is going to be centered very much around China policy, you have the potential for this to get much, much worse in the next several months.

MCDOWELL: What would you be on the lookout for?

MILLER: I think number one is the trade deal. And the reason it's so important is that the trade deal, to some degree, has kept the two sides in line, because President Trump if he wants his purchases, has to make sure to keep some of the more anti-China people in Congress, tough on China people in Congress at bay.

And I think that if this falls by the wayside, then it's going to be a scrum not just to the Republican side, but also the Democrat side to see who could look tough on about China into November. So this is really the bellwether for the fall.

MCDOWELL: I want to get to this mysterious seeds from China. Agriculture departments from four states are warning people not to plant these seeds, in case they are are invasive species or could endanger other crops or livestock.

Based on photos, these seeds appear to have been mailed in white pouches displaying Chinese lettering and the words China Post. Leland, what do you know about this?

MILLER: Well, I know what I've read about this, which is it's probably just yet another scam coming out of China. If this is the first stage of biological warfare, then it's a pretty stupid time to be doing it.

So, look, if you're getting seeds from China don't plant them. There are laws against those types of seeds coming in the country. They should be enforced. A lot of this is coming through Amazon which needs to - we need to tighten its policies. But I look at things like this and I think there's much more chance you're just seeing a couple guys in China trying to make a few bucks than anything that's systemic or coming from Beijing.

MCDOWELL: Maria spoke with Bridgewater Associates Co-Chairman Ray Dalio on "Sunday Morning Futures" yesterday about what investors need to think about before working with Chinese companies. Listen to this Leland, I'll get your reaction.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: I know that you are a global investor and you look for growth across the world. Would you still want to invest in China given what we have learnt about the Communist Party?

RAY DALIO, BRIDGEWATER ASSOCIATES CO-CHAIRMAN: I think there are three things - three big things going on and they operate together and those are the important ones. The first is where we are in the debt cycle, the printing of money, and that.

The second is how we are with each other. That we're having an ideological Civil War. And then you have the rising power of China challenging the existing power. We are in a conflict with China. You can call it a war like the 1930s. So that there is a - there's a trade war, there's a technology war, there is a geopolitical war, and there could be a capital war.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: Leland, what do you say to that?

MILLER: Well, I broadly agree with it. I think one of the things that's left unsaid there is that, the idea of decoupling is not flipping an on switch or flipping and off switch. There's a lot of degrees of decoupling that are involved. And I think what a lot of companies are doing right now is looking at the vulnerabilities in their supply chains. They're realizing that they have to do something about that whether it's because--

MCDOWELL: We lost Leland, but you know who can pick up that thought, Mitch Roschelle, because he's done so much work on it.

ROSCHELLE: Yes, and--

MCDOWELL: Vulnerability - Mitch, vulnerability of supply change. Go.

ROSCHELLE: Yes. And the thing that I think became most apparent in all of this was how dependent we are for China for pharmaceuticals. And I think that the real interesting play here may be - no one's talking about USMCA the way they should be, and have the administration put that deal together and how we could domestically source in North America, a supply chain for pharmaceuticals and other vital elements for not just manufacturing, but just for our lives.

So I think the real story here is that the administration made that deal, and if we can get our act together with China and Mexico - excuse me, Mexico and Canada, we really could have less reliance on China and that could be a very strong sign for our economy going forward.

MCDOWELL: Politically, Lee Carter, the strongest message out of President Trump when he was running for the highest office in the land was speaking to all of those Americans who had lost their jobs, their livelihoods, who had lost the safety net that they had with the company that they work for, because those jobs were shipped to other countries, particularly China over a period of decades. Does that still stand up here? Because you're really not hearing that specific message from the president as much as four years ago?

CARTER: You know, what's really interesting is right before the pandemic hit, the President was very much running on promises made, promises kept. And if you remember what he ran on? It was China, it was jobs, it was the economy, it was bringing manufacturing back. It was giving hope to these people who had lost it.

He was starting to talk about how he had brought back jobs, how he had gotten tough on China. And I think the President does need to start repeating that message, because it's really, really important to the American people. And the number one issue that's most important to Americans right now is jobs, is the economy and part of that is getting tough on China.

And so I think he does need to reframe this argument. I think the China narrative has sort of gotten away from him. And I think, frankly, it's time that he takes that back if he wants to get stronger on it as he gets close to election.

MCDOWELL: Real quickly. So the tagline from Joe Biden is "Build Back Better," which reminds me of a children's book I had when I was little called the B Book. It was big brown bear, blue bull, blowing bubbles biking backward, bump black bug's banana boxes. Anyway, I've been wanting to say that on TV. I digress.

But in terms of "Build Back Better," does that resonate with people? I know it's a lot of a alliteration from anxious anchors. But the - I don't know what that means. Are we build in back to our former relationship with China where we basically laid down and let that Communist country roll over us?

CARTER: I really think it's an interesting approach for him, because there was so much criticism about Donald Trump saying "Make America Great Again," rather like going back, right? And now it's talking about making it better, as if. And so I think that there's going to be a lot of pushback on this.

And I think you're right. The question is what does this mean? The one thing that the President did when he was "Make America Great Again," he had five signature policies. Everybody knew what they were, and you could repeat them over and over again. We're not sure what "Build Back Better" mean, and I think he's going to have to define it for us in very clear terms.

MCDOWELL: Indeed, Lee Carter, thank you. Coming up, fleeing high tax blue state Joe Rogan setting his sights on Texas. Plus, treat for your heart, the new study shows how eating chocolate can lower your risk of heart disease. You're watching "Mornings with Maria" live on Fox Business.

MCDOWELL: The risk of sunscreen. A recent study from the Food and Drug Administration found six common chemicals found in sunscreen accumulate in the body at high levels. Studies in the past associating these ingredients with various health risk. Joining us now the Medical Director of CityMD Emergency and Family Medicine doctor, Dr. Janette Nesheiwat. Dr. Janette, great to see you. I've heard this before, but this is new.

DR. JANETTE NESHEIWAT, CITYMD MEDICAL DIRECTOR: Yes. So, Dagen, what they did was, the FDA conducted a study and they had participants apply sunblock to 75 percent of their body, and then they checked the bloodstream and checked the levels of these chemicals like oxybenzone, avobenzone, these are the first ingredients you see when you look at the back of the can of these sunscreens.

And they checked the bloodstream and they found that the chemicals, the sunscreen stayed in their system for up to 21 days. And the problem with that is, it could potentially be linked with maybe harmful effects to the body, maybe some hormonal disruptions and endocrine disruption, potentially some links to cancer.

But the American Academy of Dermatology still recommends to use sunscreen, because it's safer than the potential side effects of the sunscreen. And what the FDA also found was that there's two types of chemical - sunscreens. There's the mineral and there's chemical. Of course, they found that mineral was deemed safe and effective and is FDA approved. Mineral based sunscreens like zinc oxide, titanium dioxide were much safer.

So just keep in mind, when you apply all that sunblock, you go out in the sun, you come into contact with chlorine, a chemical reaction can occur and you could potentially have exposure to toxic chemical. So keep that in mind. Sunscreen is not the only way to protect yourself from the sun. You can wear sunglasses, wear proper clothing, stay in the shade, anytime you have that opportunity.

But we know that it's summertime, people are going to be out and about it. It's important to protect yourself, especially since skin cancer is one of the most common cancers in this country.

MCDOWELL: Right. Or umbrella, like a proper--

NESHEIWAT: Yes.

MCDOWELL: --like a proper laid out for a stroll or something I know--

NESHEIWAT: There you go.

MCDOWELL: nothing about. But I don't know how an umbrella works.

NESHEIWAT: That's right.

MCDOWELL: Good news for chocolate fans. Eating the delicious treat more than once a week could help lower your chances of developing coronary heart disease. This, according to a study from the Baylor College of Medicine in Houston. Your reaction to this and is it dark chocolate versus no chocolate?

NESHEIWAT: Yes, yes. So this was published in the Journal of Preventive Cardiology and the researchers wanted to see is there a significant link between coronary artery disease and eating chocolate. And they found that yes, if you eat chocolate about once a week in moderation, then potentially it can lower your blood pressure. It can improve blood flow and circulation to the brain and to your heart and might even have a positive impact on your HDL, which is the good cholesterol.

But the key is, which chocolate? Most likely it's the dark chocolate, because chocolates contain what's called polyphenols, flavonoids, flavonols, which are strong antioxidants. They help fight inflammation in the body, help protect your body against environmental toxins, so in that sense it can help reduce the inflammation in your blood vessels.

But the key is moderation and most likely it is dark chocolates, because they contain the most powerful, more amount I should say, of these antioxidants - the flavonoids, just like we see in fruits, vegetables and even some red wine.

MCDOWELL: Yes, right. I take Resveratrol which is derived from - which is - has the same effect as drinking red wine, but like taking a supplement just as not as much fun as having a glass of red wine.

NESHEIWAT: That's true.

MCDOWELL: You don't make friends that way. Dr. Janette, it's great to see you always.

NESHEIWAT: Great to see you too, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Dr. Janette Nesheiwat. Coming up, goodbye California. Joe Rogan ready to trade in the Golden State for some lone stars or one Lone Star State that is.

MCDOWELL: The tax flight gets another name on the list. Joe Rogan says he's moving to Texas from Los Angeles. He explained the decision on his podcast.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JOE ROGAN, THE JOE ROGAN EXPERIENCE: I just want to go somewhere in the center of the country, somewhere, it's easier to travel to both places and somewhere we have a little bit more freedom. Also, I think that where we live right here in Los Angeles is overcrowded. When you look at the economic despair, when you look at the homelessness problem that's accelerated radically over the last six, seven, 10 years, I think there's too many people here. I think it's not tenable.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: This coming after - just days after Elon Musk announced that Tesla is going to build its largest auto plant near Austin, Texas. John, your reaction to this?

LONSKI: Well, people and companies vote with their feet if they don't like the tax climate, the regulatory climate, they are going to leave. If they get tired of riots and whatnot, they're not going to stay around. I mean, look what crime did to the once great city of Detroit. You have to take all of this into consideration. And who's ever ruling these states and cities has to make sure that the average American and businesses feel comfortable, that they're willing to grow within those regions.

MCDOWELL: Well, Mitch, I'm going to quote the great poet Lyle Lovett, and say That's right. You're not from Texas. That's right. You're not from Texas. That's right. You're not from Texas, but Texas wants you anyway.

ROSCHELLE: Well, when California has a top marginal tax - income tax rate for individuals of 13.3 percent and Texas has a zero individual income tax rate, I think, that's a big catalyst for all the movement. Joe Rogan did not mention that in his remarks, but I - somehow I think he and his accountant had a conversation about it and that's part of the motivation as well.

MCDOWELL: Lee, what do you make of this? I saw there was something going around on Twitter yesterday and it was a sign. It was a - I guess, it was a GOP sign that they put up in Texas saying, "You came here, but don't bring your vote here. Mean, don't bring your big - big ass blue vote to this red state was the essence of the message.

CARTER: I think it's a fascinating thing to watch. If you look at what's happening to Florida, what's happening in Texas, there's a lot of migration there from blue states. What's interesting to me is that the local government and the governors are staying Republican, even though the states themselves are moving further and further towards the Left in a presidential election.

What that says to me is people want to keep their taxes low and they need to revisit, what are their values really, what do they want from the economy, what do they want from taxes and really get honest with themselves about what it is that they want to vote.

MCDOWELL: Space, they want space, just like Joe Rogan was talking about and I totally understand.

CARTER: Absolutely right.

MCDOWELL: I totally understand that living in a 500 square foot apartment. More "Mornings with Maria" on Fox Business live right after this.

MCDOWELL: This Fox Business alert, Google is said to be keeping employees at home until at least July 2021 as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, that's according to "The Wall Street Journal." The move impacts nearly all 200,000 full-time and contract workers across Google's parent company, Alphabet.

Mitch your reaction to this. This, potentially, as these large tech companies, maybe spread people out, and they are able to work from home. It would afford people an opportunity to work at a big tech company who lives in maybe a small red state.

ROSCHELLE: Yes, and I do wonder how much of their motivation is to broaden out their access to resources. But if other companies follow suit, without the goal of trying to access a wider net for talent pool, I think it could have an impact on commercial real estate, which it hasn't happened yet. But if we go out that far less demand for office space.

MCDOWELL: Mitch Roschelle, thank you so much, sir. And Lee Carter and John Lonski, more with you guys next time. Thank you so much for being here. Varney & Company is up right now, Stuart. Take it away.

STUART VARNEY, FBN HOST: Dagen, I do agree with you there. I think that news from Google this morning about.

urn:contentItem:5S8N-N7B1-DY9P-N0SF-00000-00New cyber laws will open up businesses to hacker blackmail2018-05-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:52ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6New cyber laws will open up businesses to hacker blackmailGareth Morgan

CYBER experts fear high-tech criminals will turn the authorities against everyday businesses - by hacking into their systems and then reporting the data breach unless a ransom is paid.

New laws called the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) come into force on May 25. Experts say it will be a game-changer as cyber extortion, or the kidnapping of personal data, is becoming one of the most lucrative tactics for hackers.

Personal information could be extracted from a company by hackers and the businesses given the opportunity to pay a ransom. If not paid, the breach is reported anonymously to the Data Protection Office, bringing the threat of large fines and regulatory nightmares.

Irish businesses need to protect themselves from an impending wave of cyber extortion as a result of this, according to cyber security expert James Canty, of Magnet Networks. "After several years of cyber crime attacks, from May onwards we will now have GDPR legislation punishable by law if your business doesn't have adequate controls in place to protect any PII [personally identifiable information] it may be holding," he said.

"This presents an opportunity for the 'ordinary cyber criminal' to obtain PII from a business and demand a ransom for not letting the authorities know they easily obtained your information."

Businesses targeted in this way receive an email with the sort of information the hackers have been able to extract. "The demand would state that the appropriate protections are not in place in the company and that information was easily extracted," said Mr Canty.

"The business will then be faced with three options - paying an extortion fee, taking the risk the criminals will report the stolen data anonymously to the Data Protection Officer, or self-declaring the data breach within 48 hours. Either of the latter two options will involve inspections, fines and a large amount of regulatory work."

"Companies need to have a next-generation firewall along with advanced endpoint protection and local real-time analysis on each machine," he added.

What is GDPR? The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) is a new set of rules to radically tighten up privacy laws across the EU. It will affect every company and organisation. It means you have a lot more rights over how personal information is handled, stored and processed.

What is 'personal information'? Lots of it is the kind of stuff you would naturally expect, such as your name, your medical information or your bank details. But it also includes your IP address and location data from your phone. This is why it's such a big deal for some of the big tech companies, like Facebook, which bases its advertising model on this kind of info.

So is it mainly tech companies affected? Not at all. Any company (or organisation) that holds any personal information about you has to sit up and pay attention.

So what do these companies have to do? When a service needs your consent to use your personal information, it has to get it clearly now. So it can't, for instance, revert to obscure 'opt-out' boxes. And if some organisation suffers a serious data breach that is likely to affect you, it will now have to tell you about it. Ordinary people are now also supposed to have easier access to their personal data from companies as well as the right to transfer that data or have it deleted altogether.

When is this actually taking effect? Enforcement of the new rules comes into effect from Friday, May 25.

What does it mean if you run a business? An awful lot. For starters, non-adherence won't be treated with the typical slaps on the wrist that have existed up to now. The penalties include fines up to (EURO)20m or 4pc of global annual turnover. Data Protection Commissioner Helen Dixon said her office wouldn't hesitate to bring down the hammer. There won't be any bedding-in period. Lots of bigger businesses will need to appoint new staff, such as a data protection officer. Smaller companies will need to check their systems are compliant and that they have some procedure for dealing with the new rights that customers have.

What about social media - will it change? Anyone with a Facebook account will have noticed messages or pop-ups recently. Mainly, it has just made its settings a little more prominent and easier to adjust. It's the same for Instagram and Whatsapp (both owned by Facebook). They're asking you to "review" your privacy settings and to accept them or quit the services.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5GGG-YG71-DYS1-01V2-00000-00New data rules threaten critical health research;The drive to protect privacy may hinder investigation of medical problems2015-07-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:11:53ZLexisNexisOPINIONPg. 14New data rules threaten critical health researchThe drive to protect privacy may hinder investigation of medical problemsBarry O'Sullivan

Patient data is like blood: life-saving and harmless to the donor when responsibly gathered.

Blood donors enter into a contract with the blood transfusion service; they give blood for the purposes of supporting the health services and saving lives. The transfusion service does not have to tell them who will receive their blood and does not have to go back and ask for permission each time their blood is used.

Patient data is a similar resource - critical to our health system, specifically to health research and the development of diagnostics and therapies. Last month in Brussels the European Council announced agreement in principle to introduce a Europe-wide general regulation on data protection; some believe it will come before the end of the year.

Much focus has fallen on the response of the big tech companies, Google, Facebook, Twitter, and how the new rules might affect their business model. Our priority in Insight Ireland is the impact on the converging areas of health research and data science.

Insight Ireland took part in a day of action in Brussels to influence the shape of regulation and ensure health research is not stymied. The danger is that, in the drive to protect consumers from commercial exploitation of their data, we will also protect patients from significant potential benefits of health data analysis.

Commercial data regulation is in its infancy. Clinical research, on the other hand, operates under a significant system of regulation, and the patient-researcher relationship is very different to that between, for example, social networker and tech giant.

He gave that tissue freely along with the personal data that makes it even more valuable to the researcher. He is not worried that the tissue or the accompanying data will be abused. He has entered into a contract of trust with the researchers, in the knowledge that the appropriate safeguards are in place.

If a patient consents to participation in a clinical trial, is it necessary that that patient be contacted again for further studies and again for a medical analysis of results? If they die, must their data die with them or can it continue to inform research? Explicit consent is imperative when dealing with commercial interests in protecting personal data, but when a patient donates tissue and data for research purposes, can we infer consent for ongoing research?

The convergence of data analytics and health research offers incredible potential for human health. Right now at Insight Ireland we have data scientists and physiotherapists working together to devise ways of optimising outcomes for joint replacement patients. We are taking enormous data sets, derived by physical sensors developed in our labs, to optimise orthopaedic rehabilitation programmes in our hospitals.

Our work is attracting the attention of clinicians across the world. These therapies are only available because we have access to patient information, willingly donated for research purposes. We do not have to keep returning to these patients for ongoing consents; the data was given in the spirit of supporting our continuing work in health innovation. There are also significant safeguards in place to prevent the misuse of this data. The patient is protected even in the absence of his or her specific consent. The patient has, at any time, the option to withdraw consent.

The public attitude to data protection has been heavily influenced by the Silicon Valley powerhouses and their perceived data grabs. However, we must adopt a totally different attitude to the use of data in publicly funded health research in particular, as the public and individual interests are self-evident. We hope that what emerges from Europe in the coming months will support and foster the continuing progress of this vital and exciting new field of human health research.

Prof Barry O'Sullivan is a director of the Insight Centre for Data Analytics and head of computer science at UCC
